title: 7 Ways to Change the Color of Your iPhone Screen or Text

steps.title: Open the Settings app.
steps.content: Open the Settings app. This is the grey cog icon. Use this method to invert colors on your iPhone screen. When a color is inverted, you'll see its opposite color.

steps.title: Tap Accessibility.
steps.content: Tap Accessibility . You may need to scroll down to find this option.

steps.title: Tap Display & Test Size.
steps.content: Tap Display & Test Size . This is underneath the Vision header.

steps.title: Toggle on "Smart Invert".
steps.content: Toggle on "Smart Invert". This will invert all colors on your iPhone screen except for images. [1] X Research source To invert all colors on your screen, including images , toggle on Classic Invert .

steps.title: Open the Settings app.
steps.content: Open the Settings app. This is the grey cog icon. Keep in mind that adding color filters can change how images and videos look.

steps.title: Tap Accessibility.
steps.content: Tap Accessibility . You may need to scroll down to find this option.

steps.title: Tap Display & Test Size.
steps.content: Tap Display & Test Size . This is underneath the Vision header.

steps.title: Tap Color Filters.
steps.content: Tap Color Filters . You can find this below the Invert options.

steps.title: Toggle on "Color Filters".
steps.content: Toggle on "Color Filters". Once this is turned on, you'll be able to select a filter and its intensity.

steps.title: Tap a filter.
steps.content: Tap a filter. You can select: Greyscale, Red/Green Filter (Protanopia), Green/Red Filter (Deuteranopia), Blue/Yellow Filter (Tritanopia), and Color Tint. You'll see a preview of the color at the top. Swipe left to view different comparison images.

steps.title: Adjust the intensity.
steps.content: Adjust the intensity. Use the sliding scale to choose an intensity. To decrease the intensity, move the circle towards the left. To increase the intensity, move the circle towards the right. If you selected Color Tint , you'll also have the option to adjust the Hue. Move the circle to select a hue. When you're finished, tap the back arrow to save your changes.

steps.title: Open the Settings app.
steps.content: Open the Settings app. This is the grey cog icon. Use this method to turn on Auto-Brightness, which will automatically adjust your iPhone's screen depending on the current light conditions.

steps.title: Tap Accessibility.
steps.content: Tap Accessibility . You may need to scroll down to find this option.

steps.title: Tap Display & Test Size.
steps.content: Tap Display & Test Size . This is underneath the Vision header.

steps.title: Toggle on "Auto-Brightness".
steps.content: Toggle on "Auto-Brightness". You can find this at the very bottom of the page. To manually change your screen brightness, open the Control Center by swiping down on the top-right corner of the screen. On iPhones with a Home button, swipe up. Tap and drag the slider up to increase the brightness, or drag it down to decrease the brightness.

steps.title: Open the Control Center.
steps.content: Open the Control Center. Swipe down on the top-right corner of the screen. On iPhones with a Home button, swipe up. Dark Mode changes the color scheme of your iPhone into a dark theme, making it easier to view in low-light places.

steps.title: Tap and hold the brightness slider.
steps.content: Tap and hold the brightness slider. This is represented by a sun icon.

steps.title: Tap Dark Mode.
steps.content: Tap Dark Mode . This will turn Dark Mode on. If it's already on, it will turn off. To schedule Dark Mode to turn on and off on a schedule, do the following: Go to Settings . Tap Display & Brightness . Tap Automatic . Tap Options . Select Sunset to Sunrise or Custom Schedule .

steps.title: Open the Control Center.
steps.content: Open the Control Center. Swipe down on the top-right corner of the screen. On iPhones with a Home button, swipe up. Night Shift changes the colors of your iPhone screen to a warmer hue, making it easier to view while transitioning into bedtime.

steps.title: Tap and hold the brightness slider.
steps.content: Tap and hold the brightness slider. This is represented by a sun icon.

steps.title: Tap Night Shift.
steps.content: Tap Night Shift . This is the center icon. To schedule Night Shift to turn on and off on a schedule, do the following: Go to Settings . Tap Display & Brightness . Tap Night Shift . Toggle on Scheduled . Tap Sunset to Sunrise or Custom Schedule .

steps.title: Open the Settings app.
steps.content: Open the Settings app. This is the grey cog icon. If you have trouble seeing transparent icons, you can make them opaque.

steps.title: Tap Accessibility.
steps.content: Tap Accessibility . You may need to scroll down to find this option.

steps.title: Tap Display & Test Size.
steps.content: Tap Display & Test Size . This is underneath the Vision header.

steps.title: Toggle on "Reduce Transparency".
steps.content: Toggle on "Reduce Transparency". This will give a solid color to app backgrounds and icons.

steps.title: Exchange your iPhone.
steps.content: Exchange your iPhone. If you decide that you want a different body color for your iPhone, you'll need to exchange it or purchase a new one. If you purchased your iPhone directly from Apple, you have 14 calendar days to return or exchange it.

steps.title: Purchase a skin or case.
steps.content: Purchase a skin or case. If you're unable to exchange your iPhone, consider purchasing a skin or case. A skin is essentially a sticker you can place over the body of your phone to change its color. A case can hide the original color while adding extra protection.
